reading_mnemonic: The little ヶ might be slightly misleading, as you'll have to read this as か. The rest is easy though, as 月 just takes a normal on'yomi reading. And since we're not talking about specific months, that means it's just げつ, making this 〜かげつ.
The reading is the kun'yomi reading. Don't type the 〜 out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached to this word.
The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned. When writing out the answer to this reading, omit the 〜 as it's only there to let you know that some other word should come before it.

The reading for this is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because it's always attached to things (so it's like jukugo). Don't write the 〜 when you're writing in the answer, just the けん portion, and you'll get this one correct.
The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji. Just add the hiragana on the end and you'll be good to go.

The reading for the kanji portion uses the kun'yomi reading. This is kind of like the reading you already learned for 形 just without the ち part. And rendaku happens too, so it becomes がた. If you can remember that, you should be able to remember this reading too!
一 uses the on'yomi you learned with it, but gets shortened, so watch out for that. The rest is as you learned it!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This verb uses the exceptional reading that 下さい also uses. So just replace the さい with る and you're good to go!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You know the on'yomi reading for 界, but you didn't learn this on'yomi reading of 世, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

What's the most hated vegetable in <vocabulary>the world</vocabulary>? <reading>Ce</reading>lery (せ), probably. The world is divided into those who love celery and those who hate celery. Which one are you?
The reading is a combination of 学校 and 中. Really, it's all on'yomi too, so you should be able to read this one. Take note of the がく turning to がっ, though.
The reading is kun'yomi (see that hiragana?) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji. Enjoy the ride!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned that reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

You've done all kinds of <vocabulary>thing</vocabulary>s in your <reading>coat</reading> (こと). If you think about it, you only wear a coat when you have things to do. Try to remember all the things you've done in a coat. It's a lot! Symbolically, your coat = all the things and <vocabulary>occurrence</vocabulary>s you've experienced, and all the <vocabulary>matter</vocabulary>s you've had to deal with in life.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading is almost the same as 交ぜる which you should be familiar with by now. It has the ま but it also has an extra じ in there. That じ is there because you intersect with a group of <reading>mage</reading>s (まじ) that catch you on fire as you walk past.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 代 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

A <vocabulary>change</vocabulary> calls for a <reading>tie</reading> (たい). If you're the new company president, or you're going in to work to start your shift, you'd better make sure you look the part, so get that tie nice and straight.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading can be derived from 付ける, a word you should have seen a few levels ago. If you know that word's reading you should be able to figure out this word's reading as well (and vice versa).

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 付 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Your <vocabulary>neighborhood</vocabulary> is full of <reading>foo</reading>ls (ふ). Fools everywhere. You're probably one too, since you live <vocabulary>nearby</vocabulary>.

The reading is kun'yomi, so here's a mnemonic to remember it: 

<vocabulary>If</vocabulary> you don't mind, could you <reading>carry</reading> (かり) this for me? <vocabulary>Supposing</vocabulary> it's not too much trouble, of course.

Okay, so 仮 uses the rare kun'yomi reading か, which you haven't learned yet, but luckily it's the same as the on'yomi you have learned! And 名 also uses a kun'yomi reading that you learned with the vocab word 名 (な). So you sort of know these readings already, but it's a lot to take in, so here's a mnemonic to help: 

The reading is so tricky for <vocabulary>kana</vocabulary> that it makes you say <reading>かな</reading>… (I wonder…) whenever you try to read it. You keep thinking, "Is the reading kana, かな? Or could it be something else, かな?" You're just not sure.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

<reading>Two car</reading>s (つか), are what you have <vocabulary>to use</vocabulary> because you're so huge you don't fit into one. You've got a British car on your left and an American car on your right, and you're driving them both at the same time.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

If you want to learn how <vocabulary>to preserve something</vocabulary> like fruits and veggies, you should start with <reading>tamots</reading> (たも), that's slang for delish tomatoes. Once they're preserved, you get to make everyone you love eat those yummy tamots. Mmm!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is just the kun'yomi reading you learned with 元, but twice, so you should be good to go!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The しゅつ gets shortened and はつ changes to ぱつ. No wonder you want to make a departure, you want to get away from crazy readings like this.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for the つ of 出, which becomes っ.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

What did you just <vocabulary>win</vocabulary>? You won a new <reading>ca</reading>r (か)!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that ふ becomes ぶ because of rendaku here.

This is a jukugo word, which means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You do know all of those, but their behaviour is a little different here. 十 (じゅう) and 分 (～ふん) together actually turn into じゅっぷん here. This is sometimes the case when using ～分 to mean "minute" in combination with certain numbers, so try to pay attention to this!

There’s a creature in front of you that’s about <vocabulary>to receive something</vocabulary>, but what is it? It’s an <reading>u</reading>ni (う), and it’s going to receive a warm welcome and an education. Picture the sea urchin receiving these things, and then going on to take an exam to prove how much education it’s received.
If you know how to read 受ける and 取る, you should be good to go.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji (except for 名 and 屋, which are kun'yomi here). If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. For な just think to 名前 (なまえ) which uses the な reading. The "name" (名前) of this city is what? It's <reading>Na</reading>goya. Watch out for rendaku changing こ to ご too.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

You want <vocabulary>to sell something</vocabulary>, but what? What can you sell that will take the least amount of work? <reading>U</reading>ni (う)! They're just hanging out in the ocean, ready for the taking. Go scoop some up, watch out for the pointy bits, and sell them for some quick cash!

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Nothing in your life is as <vocabulary>important</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>valuable</vocabulary> to you as <reading>dye</reading>s (だい). You really just love dyes more than anything else. Dyes, dyes, dyes!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the on'yomi reading, same like you learned with the kanji. That is the truth, I promise.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Your <vocabulary>true strength</vocabulary> is sealed behind two locks. <reading>Gee, two</reading> <reading>lock</reading>s (じつりょく)?! People must have been scared of your <vocabulary>true power</vocabulary> to seal it behind two locks!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Take note that the つ in じつ is turned into a small っ, though.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading of 家 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Housework</vocabulary> done in a <reading>car</reading> (か) is still housework. Think of all the times you've tidied up your car. That's housework too!

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You learned the か reading with 家事, but here's a mnemonic in case you need a refresher:

The best kind of <vocabulary>furniture</vocabulary> is a <reading>car</reading> (か). If you think about it, anybody would be impressed to find a car inside your house. Is that a car, they'd ask. Oh, that's just a piece of furniture, you'd say, I use it as a bed. Car furniture is such a flex.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the regular on'yomi reading of 小 plus the vocab word 学校 that you've seen previously. Combine these two things for the reading of 小学校.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is double kun'yomi, as you can probably guess due to all the hiragana involved. So, you double up on よわ and then add the しい to read this vocabulary word.

The reading for this one is a weird one. It uses the kun'yomi readings for both, meaning you'll have to pull your knowledge of the word 弱い from earlier and apply it here. 虫 should be okay, though, as this is the reading you learned with the kanji.

Just remember, only weak bugs use kun'yomi, and that weak bug is you in this instance.
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the words 心 and 強い, so you should be able to read this on your own. Just note that つよい gets rendaku'd to づよい!

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that the つ in ひつ is turned into a small っ, though.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

If you try <vocabulary>to hold something</vocabulary> in your hand long enough it will <reading>mo</reading>ld (も). And then that mold will cover your hand, then your arm, then your entire body. Basically, you should never hold anything for too long or you'll become a mold person.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 教える, so you should be able to read this word as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Your family buys you a <vocabulary>new</vocabulary> Atari! You're so excited! But wait... what's this? This is no Atari. This is an <reading>Atara</reading>... a knockoff video game system :(
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Do you remember the adjective 明るい (あかるい), meaning "bright"? As you can see, these words are quite similar! You just need to remember that the か in 明かり isn't part of the kanji, like in 明るい.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

A <vocabulary>star</vocabulary> is just a <reading>who</reading>le <reading>shee</reading>p (ほし) floating in the sky. If it wasn't a whole sheep, it wouldn't shine so brightly and you wouldn't be able to see it from Earth. Don't let anyone tell you stars are made of gas. The whole thing is sheep, okay?
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading with 曲げる, so you should be good to go!
The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji and uses the on'yomi even though it's a single word. Very strange, but convenient for you so long as you remember this exception reading word.
The readings are the ones that you learned with the kanji.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

You can't find your <vocabulary>tag</vocabulary> anywhere. It was just there, you swear, but now it's nowhere to be found. You search for it everywhere, then you realize... it was right there all along. Seriously? You're such a <reading>foo</reading>l, <reading>duh</reading> (ふだ)!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Something is lacking... it's a <reading>ca</reading>r (か). You can't stop thinking about this because you have to walk 40 miles to get to your destination. If only that car wasn't missing, this would be easier. Imagine the sweat... the pain... the thirst... all because that car's not present.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The readings come from the two words 気 and 付ける. So long as you know those from the previous levels, you should be able to read this one as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be sure to take note of the shortened けつ in 決. It goes to けっ.
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
The reading is kun'yomi (see that hiragana sticking out?) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

You visit the <vocabulary>sea</vocabulary>. Strangely, it asks you who is visiting. You're so full of yourself (even in front of the sea/ocean) that you reply: "<reading>um, me</reading>?" (うみ). Imagine yourself feeling this full of yourself.

You might think this is all going to be on'yomi, which it can be, but we'd actually like you to focus on the kun'yomi reading <ja>うみざかな</ja> here. Using the on'yomi is also correct, but sounds formal and scientific, while <ja>うみざかな</ja> is much more colloquial, so try to remember this reading instead! You already know the individual kun'yomi readings for this, but do watch out for the rendaku.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, but you haven't learned it yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

What game has the most <vocabulary>thing</vocabulary>s in it? <reading>Mono</reading>poly (もの). You can choose from a bunch of random things to play as, you know? And no one actually knows what those things are. What's a thimble anyway? Just call it a thing.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ひょう changes to ぴょう and the はつ gets shortened, though, so just about everything about this word is weird.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You know the はつ part, which gets shortened to はっ. The 見 is unlike what you learned with 見, though. 

In order to remember that this is けん, imagine you're going out to make a discovery of some strange new lands. With strange new lands, there comes strange new people. This one has a samurai named <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) on it. He's trying to discover new things too!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The readings are kun'yomi, but you should have seen both 白 and 黒い separately as vocabulary by now. It's the same readings here, so you can apply that knowledge and read this word!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This word uses the kun'yomi of both kanji, and you haven't learned this kun'yomi for 空 yet. As long as you know the meaning, the reading should be easy, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case:

<vocabulary>Karate</vocabulary> comes from (<reading>から</reading>) Japan!

This is a bit of a weird one, since it uses kun'yomi and not on'yomi. What's more, how you read 立 is slightly different from what you'd expect. So here's a mnemonic to help you remember how to read 立 this time:

Talking about your <vocabulary>standpoint</vocabulary> can be a <reading>touchy</reading> (たち) subject. You should watch out since people can get touchy when you give your standpoint on things!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you. It's a long reading for a mnemonic, but try your best. 

You look at someone who is <vocabulary>beautiful</vocabulary>. What an easy life they've lived. No hard work and all they do is pamper themselves to stay beautiful. Feel disgusted. You walk up to this person and say: "<reading>U too cushy</reading>! (うつくしい). 

Sorry for adding the whole word in there for the reading mnemonic, but I thought it worked out better that way. Just know that the word isn't うつくしいしい or something weird like that. The hiragana on the end is part of the mnemonic as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Where you're from, every <vocabulary>beautiful woman</vocabulary> wears <reading>bee</reading> <reading>jean</reading>s (びじん). That's right, jeans made out of bees. Beauty knows no pain after all!
For 肉 you use the にく reading (which you learned with the kanji). For 屋 you use the kun'yomi, which you learned with the kanji. Basically, if you learned the kanji readings, you can read this word!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Everything is really <vocabulary>painful</vocabulary> right now. Why? You have something heavy on top of you, <reading>cru</reading>shing (くる) you.
This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're standing there, staring at <vocabulary>the front</vocabulary> of this building. You spend some time gazing at it before you realize what it is. "<reading>Oh</reading>, <reading>mote</reading>l (おもて)," you say aloud. <vocabulary>The surface</vocabulary> of this building really gave it away. "Oh, motel!"

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're trying not to say it directly, but trying to figure out how <vocabulary>to express something</vocabulary>. That something is that you <reading>are a wuss</reading> (あらわす). Sorry, had to be expressed.

Since the reading isn't like the one you learned, think about what you are going <vocabulary>to need</vocabulary>... like, what you're really going to need, more than anything. Then, think of an <reading>ea</reading>gle, because you really need an eagle. You'll need to come up with the reason why you need an eagle though, so hopefully it's a good one.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The readings come from 見る and 付ける. If you use those readings, you'll be able to read this word too.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
You know how when you try to do something you put your whole heart into it? Well, think of that in Japanese. You put your whole <reading>心</reading> (こころ) into it.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You lose your tournament/soccer game/whatever (you decide something applicable to you). You're sad about this. Who's there to comfort you? Your <reading>Ma</reading> (ま). She's a nice lady.

Depending on the context, the reading for this word could be からい or つらい. 

The からい reading is the <vocabulary>spicy</vocabulary> one that you learned with the kanji, which you can remember because spicy foods give a <reading>から</reading>て chop to your mouth. 

The つらい reading is the <vocabulary>difficult</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>painful</vocabulary> one. You can remember this because <reading>two Ra</reading>s (つら) are way more difficult to deal with than one Ra.
This is the kun'yomi readings together. You should have learned them both by now.
The reading is 辛い (からい) and the on'yomi reading for 子 combined together. It's one of those weird words that mixes the on'yomi and kun'yomi readings.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have <vocabulary>to return</vocabulary> the <reading>Ca</reading>r <reading>e</reading>gg (かえ) you found on the side of the road. It will birth a little car, but it needs its mother. So, you try to figure out how to return it. Go ahead and think through that process in your mind. Also think about how weird a car egg would be.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You need to send an entire <reading>oak</reading> (おく) tree in the mail, but it's too big. Imagine yourself dragging one to the post office. They tell you that you can't send that here... Go to the oak sending facilities.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 通る. Switch the る for a す and you'll be all set!
The reading is the same as the word 通る, so as long as you know that, you should be able to read this one as well. Mind the strange long お sound!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

部屋 is a bit tricky because it's one of the few Japanese words that use the へ reading for 部. You'll just have to remember this one is special. Here's a mnemonic to help you out:

Imagine you're renting out a <vocabulary>room</vocabulary>, but all you hear at night is a constant "<reading>heh</reading> (<ja>へ</ja>)… heh... heh... hehehe". An incessant snickering, coming from somewhere inside your room. Hehehe.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Use the reading of 高い (たかい) to help you to learn and remember the reading for this one. They're the same except for the hiragana at the end.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Use the reading of 高校 from before to learn the reading of this word as well, if it helps.

The kun'yomi reading is used for the 魚 (so it's さかな) and the kun'yomi reading is used for 屋 (や). You'll have to use the reading of 魚 from the vocabulary from a couple levels ago to remember the reading of this one.
